Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a High-Density Microelectrode Array for Recording and Stimulating Hundreds of Neurons
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to Indiana University, Bloomington, to acquire a 512 micro-electrode array instrument (512MEA) for recording and stimulating electrical activity in samples of brain tissue. The 512MEA can be used to measure how groups of several hundred neurons send information back and forth to each other. The ability to map information transfer in networks of this size is expected to be very valuable. Many theories predict that information transfer will change in networks of hundreds of neurons after learning, after exposure to drugs of addiction or toxins, after seizures and after traumatic injury. Other theories predict that brain networks process information in a nearly optimal way, an idea that has remained largely untested. Use of the 512MEA is therefore expected to provide new knowledge relevant to understanding how learning occurs, how drug addiction begins, how poisons affect brain health, how epileptic seizures start, how the brain responds to injury, and how the brain optimizes information processing. Ultimately, this work could benefit society by helping to improve teaching and learning in schools, by helping in the treatment of epilepsy patients, people exposed to harmful substances, war veterans, and by suggesting new ways to design brain-like computers. To maximize the number of students and laboratories using this device, it will be rotated between the Department of Physics, the Department of Brain and Psychological Sciences, and the Medical School.

The research and training opportunities that are opened by the 512MEA center on two topics of investigation: (1) emergent properties, and (2) information transfer. Emergent Properties: Many basic emergent properties of the brain like pattern recognition, associative memory, formation of cell assemblies, neuronal avalanches, synchronized pulses, and collective computations are predicted to arise first in populations of hundreds of interconnected neurons. Although most of these phenomena have been predicted for decades, they have remained largely unexplored for lack of proper instrumentation. The 512MEA would allow all of these topics to be researched in detail, many for the first time. Information transfer: It is almost completely unknown how information transfer differs in networks from naive animals and those that have learned; between networks exposed to neuro-active substances and those that have not; between developing networks and those that have matured. Because the 512MEA can record neural activity at millisecond resolution, it can identify which brain cell became active first in a chain of activity. This ability is crucial, as it will indicate the direction of influence between neurons. Optical methods of recording activity between hundreds of neurons often do not have this capability. The 512MEA can thus permit many of these topics to be researched for the first time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this grant was to fund the construction and purchase of a specialized electrode array system for use in many neuroscience labs at Indiana University. This has been successfully accomplished. Below, more detailed descriptions are given of the device, its purpose, its broader impacts, its present status and its future use.

The device consists of an array of 512 very tiny electrodes that are densely spaced. The design of this device is optimized for recording electrical activity from small sections of brain tissue. The complete system consists of the electrode array, a computer with electronics for recording and processing data, and associated electronics so that individual brain cells can be electrically stimulated.

The purpose of the device is to allow scientists to explore in more detail how networks consisting of hundreds of closely-spaced, connected brain cells work together to process information. Just as the processing of information in a computer requires hundreds and thousands of transistors working together, it is thought that information processing in the brain is accomplished by hundreds and thousands of neurons working together. With this electrode array system, scientists are able to monitor the electrical signals sent and received by hundreds of neurons simultaneously. This is a major advance, as much previous work looked at one or only a few brain cells at a time. With this device it becomes possible to observe how large groups of brain cells cooperate in information processing. The system can also be used to stimulate hundreds of neurons in complex patterns in space and time, like those thought to be produced by sensory experiences. This device can enable experiments to be done that were not possible a few years ago.

The broader impacts of the device can be broken down into two general categories: the scientific impact and the societal impact:

The scientific impact of this device arises from its ability to record activity in hundreds of connected brain cells at the same time at high temporal precision. Many theories of brain function predict that groups of a hundred or so brain cells will be capable of performing collective computations like recognition of visual patterns, storage of memories, and the association, or linking, of different memories together. With this system, these predictions can be evaluated for the first time. The system will allow comparison of brain network activity between animals with epilepsy and those without; between animals that have learned a new task and those that are naïve; between animals that have received a drug treatment and those that have not. Brain technology has been very good at looking at whole brain activity or the activity of one to eight neurons. Strangely, very little work has been done at the scale of hundreds of connected neurons. This device allows scientists to peer into this middle scale of the brain with impressive detail.  

The societal impact is expected to come from discoveries accomplished by experimenting with networks of neurons at this neglected scale. The initiation of epileptic seizures is thought to be caused by groups of neurons misfiring their activity. Learning a new memory is thought to be accomplished by groups of neurons activating each other through a network of strengthened connections, or synapses. By stimulating networks of these brain cells in the appropriate patterns, it is thought that memories could be imprinted and networks could be made seizure-prone. Observing these processes will provide new information that could lead to new treatments of diseases that cause society untold human suffering and enormous financial losses. Another aspect of societal impact is that this device will allow scientists to observe in close detail how living neural networks process information. This may facilitate the improvement of artificial neural networks that are currently used to recognize faces, translate text and autonomously drive cars. Improvements in these devices by making them more brain-like could increase the quality of life for billions of people.

The present status of the device is that it is being used in the lab of Professor John Beggs. There were some initial delays in getting the device running because of renovations at the physics department building. This necessitated the entire Beggs lab moving across campus to another building. The device has been successfully moved and after this delay it will be tested further and then used for a period of data collection.

The future plans for the device include rotations to the labs of Ken Mackie and then Xiaoming Jin at Indiana University. After that, it will be available for other labs at Indiana University as well. The cost of system maintenance will be provided by collecting fees from the labs that use it.
